children.value: Docker is a new and upcoming technology, this post walks through a high level overview of Docker and how you might incorporate it in to your workflow.
Docker is a way to package applications and the associated dependencies into a single unit called an image
This image can then be shared and run as a container
, either locally as a developer, or remotely in your production infrastructure.
Lightweight in comparison to virtual machines
Quickly testing disposable containers which run arbitrary software
By default the container's file systems are isolated from your host machine's file system
Runs in userspace. You can't test kernel exploits, run freebsd, run windows containers on linux, etc.
Not really intended for graphical applications, even with X11 forwarding tricks etc.
To run nginx, a simple web server, in a container the following can be used in your terminal:
The important parts to note are:
- We wish to run a command in a container
- the image name that we want to run. Docker will download this, and create a container
- automatically remove the container when the command exits
- publish a container's ports to the host
to see that the nginx server is running and available on your host machine:

properties.ariaLabel: where did the nginx image come from permalink

children.value: Where did the nginx image come from?
Docker will first check locally for the required image
if it is not found it will attempt to download it
. In this case the nginx image was retrieved from
You can also directly search Docker Hub for any additional images that you require:

The Docker CLI can interact with other repositories too. For instance you can run your own private repositories if you are part of a large organization. You can view the current configuration for the Docker with
Note that the above output uses the terminology
. The Docker CLI is the Client which interacts with the Server. The Docker daemon generally runs on the host machine, but you can also interact with remote Docker servers.

properties.ariaLabel: how did docker know to run nginx permalink

children.value: How did docker know to run nginx?
The  docker image will specify a single command to run
When that process ends, the docker container will stop
. We can use the docker CLI tools to inspect a particular image and see its configuration. If we look closely, we can clearly see the
allows you to specify an arbitrary command:
This will take precedence over the default

hello from inside of the container
$
you can run this container with an interactive pseudo-tty
. This allows you to run arbitrary commands from within the container in a similar manner to having SSH'd in to the container:

hello from inside the container
root@2c0645b7bba2:/
You will often find the shorthand flags being used to achieve the same effect:

properties.ariaLabel: how do i run older versions of software permalink

children.value: How do I run older versions of software?
Similar to Git, Docker uses tags for versioning images. The format
is used. If you don't specify a specific tag within the run command, it will default to

docker run --rm nginx
docker run --rm nginx:latest
docker run --rm nginx:1.19.5
docker run --rm nginx:1.7.1
Docker Hub also provides a searchable list of the available tags:

properties.ariaLabel: creating your own docker images permalink

children.value: Before we get started writing our images, here's some terminology to consider:
- Contains a sequence of steps to create the final docker image(s)
- A layer will be created for each step in your Dockerfile
- The set of files which we can reference during the image build process
- An immutable snapshot of your software dependencies. Think OOP classes.
- A running version of your image. Think OOP instances.
Let's run through a quick example for
. Our application is extremely simple, the folder structure will look like:
file will use Flask to host a simple hello world server on port 8000:
# Inside of your application code, preference binding to 0.0.0.0
The python application depends on Flask, so we can make use of
Finally we can create the new
which will define how to build our image:
# FROM - The base image to use
# WORKDIR - Specify the working directory; Future ADD/COPY/CMD/RUN commands will execute within this directory
# COPY - files from the docker context in to the current layer
# COPY - The remaining context files to the current image's filesystem
# CMD - Specify the default command to run the flask application
Docker will sequentially run through each command in your Dockerfile. Common commands are:
- Specify a base image to run the following commands on
- Run arbitrary commands from within the context of that layer
-Specify the working directory; Future ADD/COPY/CMD/RUN commands will execute within this directory
- Copy files from the docker build context in to the image's filesystem
- Default command to run within a container if none is specified
is used to specify the build context. Docker will look for a

by default in the directory, however you can also manually specify both. Generally it's best to follow the normal convention of keeping your Dockerfile in the top level of the project that you're developing. You can specify other parameters if you wish:
Let's see the full build results:
Sending build context to Docker daemon

Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/41/ad/6a4f1a124b325618a7fb758b885b68ff7b058eec47d9220a12ab38d90b1f/zipp-3.4.0-py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: virtualenv-clone, distlib, filelock, appdirs, zipp, importlib-metadata, six, virtualenv, certifi, pipenv
Successfully installed appdirs-1.4.4 certifi-2020.11.8 distlib-0.3.1 filelock-3.0.12 importlib-metadata-3.1.0 pipenv-2020.11.15 six-1.15.0 virtualenv-20.2.1 virtualenv-clone-0.5.4 zipp-3.4.0
WARNING: You are using pip version

.4 is available.
You should consider upgrading via the
Some interesting points to note about this process:
Docker will execute each command sequentially
The result of each command will result in a new layer
Each intermediate layer has a unique id
Tags are aliases. One image id can have multiple tags. For instance
Docker will cache layers if the build context is not modified
If we rerun the build command again, it will finish immediately
. Note that the image ids are identical to the previous run:

latest .
Sending build context to Docker daemon

RUN pip install pipenv
 ---> Using cache
 --->

COPY Pipfile Pipfile.lock ./
 ---> Using cache
 ---> b

If the docker daemon notices that the build context has changed for a particular layer, the cache is invalidated for that step, as well as subsequent steps. It is for this reason we always copy package dependencies first to ensure expensive package installs are cached.
We can now run the application, and publish the docker's ports to the host machine:

* Environment: production
   WARNING: This is a development server. Do not use it

a production deployment.
   Use a production WSGI server instead.
 * Debug mode: off
 * Running on http://127.0.0.1:80/
We can use curl to ensure that everything is working as intended:
In some scenarios we may notice our build context is far larger than expected.  This is how we can
reduce the files sent to the build context
Sending build context to Docker daemon
Now we can see that the build context has been dramatically reduced in size:
Sending build context to Docker daemon
Reduce build speeds. Creating the build context can be slow
Reduce the chance of cache invalidation
Ensure the final image doesn't contain contain sensitive files such as

Earlier it was mentioned that each step within a Dockerfile will become a layer. These layers combine will produce the final runnable image. These layers can be downloaded separately, and in parallel. Note that if you have previous layers already, they won't be downloaded again:

ruby

d77915b4e630: Pull complete
5f37a0a41b6b: Pull complete
96b2c1e36db5: Pull complete
c495e8de12d2: Downloading
Create a tag TARGET_IMAGE that refers to SOURCE_IMAGE
You can view every layer with the

my_image
IMAGE               CREATED             CREATED BY                                      SIZE                COMMENT
72938d6b403c
Let's say we had the following docker build break:
Sending build context to Docker daemon
ERROR:: --system is intended to be used
pre-existing Pipfile installation, not installation of specific packages. Aborting.
Each intermediate docker stage has a unique id
that can be used to run commands against arbitrary intermediate stages of a docker build. This is great for debugging broken builds.
We can run the step prior to failure within an interactive shell
# The build failed. Let's use the previous image id:
Sending build context to Docker daemon
# Run a new command against the intermediate step. Note that alpine doesn't have `/bin/bash`:
If you're having problems with an already running docker container and you're not sure what's going wrong, you can use
to run an arbitrary command against a currently running container. This works in a similar way to
# View the running containers to see the container id (Same as `docker container ls`)

CONTAINER ID        IMAGE               COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS              PORTS                    NAMES
223129cea261        nginx
# exec an interactive tty against an existing container
You can also name docker containers
# Run an arbitrary container with a name
By default when you run a container it will run in the foreground of your terminal. However, it is also possible the process in the background using detached mode:
# -d, --detach  Run container in background and print container ID
It is possible to view the logs of any container, whether attached or not, with

CONTAINER

Fetch the logs of a container

command can also be useful to attach to the previously detached docker container. Although even in this scenario I would more frequently use
standard input, output, and error streams to a running container
If you're trying to debug locally, rather than on production, the final trick is to
remove the -d flag, and view the error synchronously

Docker is great for running stand alone, portable, applications and software. It can be used to create images for building/compiling software in your CI environments, or for local development purposes.

Let's say I wanted to cross compile software for a different architecture than my host machine. Setting up cross-compilers on your own machine can be complicated. Instead we can create an replicable build environment using Docker. This was the approach that I took as part of developing my
. Let's create a simple Dockerfile for this:
# Copy standalone script for installing cross compilers
# Add the cross compiler to the path, to ensure 'i386-elf-gcc' is now available
The docker image can be built as normal:
Now we can run the container as normal. However, we will
use Docker's volumes to ensure that our source files are available on Docker's file system

file. Note that the database url references the container name, which docker will resolve:

Kubernetes takes the art of running multi-container applications a step further. It also supports yaml configuration. However, it provides additional complexities such as application autoscaling, and deployment management of your production cluster. Although Kubernetes is more of a production tool, Docker for Desktop has support for Kubernetes:

You may try starting an interactive container, for it to immediately fail with the following error. Try using

$ docker run -it --rm some_image /bin/bash
docker: Error response from daemon: OCI runtime create failed: container_linux.go:346: starting container process caused
: stat /bin/bash: no such file or directory"

properties.ariaLabel: containers running out of memory permalink

children.value: If you're running large Java docker containers, they may run out of memory. Depending on the configuration the containers may restart frequently, or start and immediately die. The 137 exit status code is generally an indicator that the docker container has been killed due to memory constraints. You can configure this limit:

children.value: Host Machine running out of memory
You may have no longer needed containers / images that you wish to remove:
Firstly, there are build stage security issues:
file correctly can lead to files being copied from your docker context in to the final image unintentionally, for instance the contents of
. For images that are running web servers, this may lead to these files being accessible to publicly, or if the images are distributed users may gain access to secrets unintentionally.
Do not inline passwords/credentials in your Dockerfile commands, they can be seen with

Do not use intermediate stages if credentials/sensitive files are used. Ensure they are 'atomic' and no longer exist at the end of the stage - otherwise if the intermediate layer can be run in isolation, it's possible to to retrieve the credentials. Always check the latest best practices.
Additionally there are run time security issues:
If you don't specify an IP with
. This may or may not be a security concern for your use case and set up.

Mounted volumes allows for files to be shared between the container and the host machine. This also means if the docker container runs as root, it can write files on the host with root permissions, potentially with the SUID bit set - potentially leading to local privilege escalation.

Docker in docker is possible by mounting the docker socket in a container. If the container gets compromised - then the child container can interact with the mounted docker socket to create a new container with custom options, including mounting the host file system directly, allowing access to arbitrary files - potentially including
etc. This problem also exists if a user is granted write permissions to this socket with
When testing software, Docker also provides a
flag when running containers, and read-only volumes
